trial_identification.studytitle: Evaluation of psychological therapy for adolescents with sleep disturbance.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A randomised controlled trial of cognitive-behaviour therapy for adolescents diagnosed with delayed sleep phase disorder: evaluation of sleep, sleepiness, and mood.
trial_identification.secondaryid: This trial does not have a secondary ID

interventions.interventions: Cognitive-behaviour therapy; six 50-min individual sessions over 8 weeks. Cognitive-behaviour therapy involves education about sleep, sleep hygiene, evening dim light, morning bright light therapy, and cognitive therapy for insomnia.
interventions.comparator: Waitlist Control; no treatment for 8 weeks; afterwards provided with cognitive-behaviour therapy as per the intervention group.

primaryOutcome.outcome: total sleep time; measured via self-reported 7-day sleep diary
primaryOutcome.timepoint: total sleep time measured at pre-treatment, post-treatment, and 6-month follow-up.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: sleep onset time; measured via self-reported 7-day sleep diary
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: sleep onset time measured at pre-treatment, post-treatment, and 6-month follow-up.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Sleep timing is significantly delayed relative to socially conventional times (eg, school start time), evidenced by a chronic inability to sleep and wake at desired times. May have associated insomnia and daytime sleepiness symptoms. Sleep disturbance significantly impacts on at least 1 important area of life (eg, school attendance/performance).
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Sleep disturbance is better explained by another sleep disorder (eg, insomnia, insomnia due to a mental disorder); atypical development (ie, diagnosed intellectual ability, autistic spectrum disorder); younger than 11 yrs and older than 18 yrs.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The aim of the study is to evaluate cognitive-behaviour therapy (CBT) for adolescents with delayed sleep. It is hypothesised that CBT will result in more night-time sleep and fall asleep earlier.
ethicsAndSummary.publication: Gradisar, M., Dohnt, H., Gardner, G., Paine, S., Starkey, K., Slater, A., Menne, A., Wright, H., Trenowden, S., & Hudson, J.L. A randomised controlled trial of cognitive behaviour therapy for adolescent Delayed Sleep Phase Disorder. Journal of Sleep Research, 19 (Suppl. 2), 31.
